p: The microstructure of interactions between starch granules and fungi were observed using SEM. SEM micrographs of A. flavus or A. ochraceus on grains after treatment with EOCs are shown in Figure 2. Many A. flavus mycelium and visible spores were distributed on the surface of granules, and the release of internal starch contents from boundary damage in grains was noticeable ( Figure 2A). Similarly, A. ochraceus affected the integrity of starch granules seriously and resulted in some partial disruption of starches ( Figure 2D). It was speculated that the mold occupied space gaps among starch granules and consumed nutrients, thus eroding the rice grains. After treatment with geraniol, starches appeared to follow healthy development with a regular crystalline form ( Figure 2B) and were much larger than that in Figure 2A, revealing that geraniol not only effectively prevented the infection of A. flavus and A. ochraceus on grains, but also maintained the complete structure of granules without harmful side effects.
